An element $e \in M$ is called a unit element or a neutral element with respect to the law of composition on $M$ if $ea = a = ae$ holds for all $a \in M$. Such a unit element $e$ is uniquely determined by its defining property; it is usually denoted as 1.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Unit or Neutral Element need to be defined for a definition of a/an Orbit to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an Orbit involves the action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \text{ in } X$ is defined as the set of all elements obtained by applying every element of the group $G$ to $x$. This definition does not inherently require the concept of a unit or neutral element. However, the definition of a group $G$ inherently includes the existence of a unit or neutral element. This neutral element in the context of group theory ensures that for every element $g \text{ in } G$, there exists an identity element $e$ such that $eg = ge = g$. This identity element is crucial for the structure of the group but does not directly influence the definition of an orbit except for ensuring that the original element $x$ is included in the orbit as $ex = x$. Thus, while the concept of a unit or neutral element is essential for the definition of the group, it is not directly necessary for the definition of an orbit, but it indirectly influences the properties of the orbit by ensuring that $x$ is included in $Gx$.
